questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT
-

You have an Azure subscription that contains the resources shown in the following table.

//IMG//


share1 stores FSLogix profile containers and is backed up daily to Vault1.

You need to change the backup location of share1 to Vault2.

Which two settings should you modify for Vault1 to prepare for the change? To answer, select the appropriate settings in the answer area.

NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

//IMG//

discussion.content:
Correct.

Backup policies: Ensures Share1 is no longer governed by Vault1’s backup schedules.

Backup Infrastructure: Removes Share1’s registration from Vault1, allowing it to be re-registered in Vault2.

Why not other options?

Site Recovery/Recovery Plans: Irrelevant for Azure Files backup.

Networking/Properties/Locks: Do not control backup registration or policies.

questions.question_text:
You have an Azure Virtual Desktop deployment that contains a host pool named Pool1. Pool1 contains five Windows 11 session hosts.

You need to identify which Azure Virtual Desktop client app versions are used to connect to the session hosts in Pool1.

What should you use?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Azure Virtual Desktop Insights provides detailed monitoring and diagnostics specific to AVD, including client app versions used to connect to session hosts. It aggregates data from Azure Monitor and Log Analytics to track client connectivity details.

Why not other options?

A (Application Insights): Focuses on application performance telemetry, not AVD client versions.

C (Insights for VMs): Monitors VM performance (CPU, memory), not client app details.

D (Insights for Pool1): Not a valid Azure service.

Selected Answer: B
B Azure virtual desktop insights
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/virtual-desktop/insights-use-cases

Selected Answer: B
No, adding a lock on Host1 will not prevent new user sessions from being established. Instead, you should:

Drain the session host: This can be done by setting the session host to “drain mode” in the Azure portal. This will prevent new user sessions from being directed to Host1 while allowing existing sessions to continue until they are logged off.

After you answer a question in this section, you will NOT be able to return to it. As a result, these questions will not appear in the review screen.

You have an Azure Virtual Desktop host pool that runs Windows 10 Enterprise multi-session.

User sessions are load-balanced between the session hosts. Idle session timeout is 30 minutes.

You plan to shut down a session host named Host1 to perform routine maintenance.

You need to prevent new user sessions to Host1 without disconnecting active user sessions.

Solution: From the Azure portal, add lock on Host1.

Does this meet the goal?

discussion.content: A is correct

Selected Answer: A
A- explanation: Azure Backup supports backing up virtual machines (like WVDVM-0) and Azure file shares (like share1). However, custom images in a shared image gallery (Image1) and images stored in Azure Blob storage (Image2) are not directly supported by Azure Backup. Instead, they can be protected by replicating or creating snapshots, but not through the Azure Backup service. Therefore, only the VM and file share can be backed up using Azure Backup.

A- explanation: Azure Backup supports backing up virtual machines (like WVDVM-0) and Azure file shares (like share1). However, custom images in a shared image gallery (Image1) and images stored in Azure Blob storage (Image2) are not directly supported by Azure Backup. Instead, they can be protected by replicating or creating snapshots, but not through the Azure Backup service. Therefore, only the VM and file share can be backed up using Azure Backup.

Selected Answer: A
A. WVDVM-0 and share1 only

comments.content: NM, I retract this post. I realized that C has listed "Image1" that cannot be backed up using Azure backups.

discussion.content:
The answer is C. See below the list of what Azure Backup can back up:
On-premises - Back up files, folders, system state using the Microsoft Azure Recovery Services (MARS) agent. Or use the DPM or Azure Backup Server (MABS) agent to protect on-premises VMs (Hyper-V and VMware) and other on-premises workloads
Azure VMs - Back up entire Windows/Linux VMs (using backup extensions) or back up files, folders, and system state using the MARS agent.
Azure Managed Disks - Back up Azure Managed Disks
Azure Files shares - Back up Azure File shares to a storage account
SQL Server in Azure VMs - Back up SQL Server databases running on Azure VMs
SAP HANA databases in Azure VMs - Backup SAP HANA databases running on Azure VMs
Azure Database for PostgreSQL servers - Back up Azure PostgreSQL databases and retain the backups for up to 10 years
Azure Blobs - Overview of operational backup for Azure Blobs

Selected Answer: A
Agree that A is the correct answer
